classitems.description:
In order to flag an advert to potentially be shown, you call this function with appropriate data blocks as defined below. You should pause your game play whilst the advert is displayed, and thus you should consider the advert to be displayed, until the console triggers the result member function of the return value.
If you declare your data type to be interstitial, then the advert (currently) will be triggered always. If you declare your data type to be levelStarted, then the advert may or may not fire based upon the behaviour defined in the game_details.json file. If the advert isn't fired, the result is fired immediately. In this case, any code appearing on lines after this call will be called after the result callback is fired, whereas if the advert is fired, any code appearing on lines after this call will be called before the result is fired. Therefore, you should consider pausing all game execution prior to this call, and leave this as the last call to make.

params.name: data
params.description:
An object which contains either 
{
   type: 'interstitial'
}
to fire interstitial adverts all the time, or: 
{
   type: 'levelStarted',
   level: num
}
where num is the level number as an integer that the user is about to start playing. In this instance the advert display behaviour is guided by the game_details.json file.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the advert is dismissed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that currently is empty, when the advert has dismissed.

example:
iConsole.ads.show( {
   type: 'levelStarted',
   level: 3
} ).result( function( resultData ) {
   myGame.startGameTimer();
} );
classitems.name: show

classitems.description:
This is the first call you need to make in order for the game and the console to start communicating with
each other. This call will return an object that you'll need to register a callback handler with, that will
be triggered after the pre-game advert has dismissed. You will need to prevent game play taking place until
this callback has been triggered, otherwise the game will start playing with an advert sat on top.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the advert is dismissed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains a key user that is an object of the user data.

classitems.name: ready

classitems.description:
While the game is loading all of it's assets, you should call this frequently to notify the user (via the
pre-game advert progress bar) of the game's loading progress. Typically games will pre-load the image /
audio assets needed for the menu and first level of the game. Games may also use this time to pre-compile any
data blocks that may require a degree of time to complete

params.name: data
params.description:
an object contains mappings to:
progress a floating point number from 0 to 1 that indicates the progress the game is making in preparing the game for presentation ot the user. At 1 (i.e. 100%) the game should be in a state (once the pre-game advert has been dismissed) where the user can play or view a menu screen with no further loading screens.
file a string containing the file asset you are loading, or it can be a debug message to indicate what you are processing. If debug is enabled in the javascript console, the console will log out the game loading percentage and this file name/message

return.description: The return object is not needed.

classitems.name: loadProgress

classitems.description: Once the game has finished loading all of it's assets you should call this method to notify the console that you have completed loading of all game assets and pre-compilation. This is in addition to making an iConsole.game.loadProgress( { progress: 1, file: '' } ); call. This call to iConsole.game.loaded indicates to the console that it should allow the user to dismiss the pre-game advert (once the minimum advert time has passed), or if the maximum advert time has passed to immediately dismiss the pre-game advert. This call will ultimately result in the callback function in iConsole.game.ready to be called.

params.name: data
params.description:
either: 
{
   success: true
}
indicating that the game has successfully loaded, or 
{
   success: false,
   item: 'The item that caused the game to fail loading',
   text: 'Any debug information that may help understand why the game failed to load'
}
indicating that the game failed to load, where item and text are both strings that are used to identify to the console and developer why the game failed to load.

return.description: The return object is not needed.

example:
iConsole.game.loaded( {
   success: false,
   item: 'audio/background_music.mp3',
   text: 'Error fetching file'
} );
classitems.name: loaded

classitems.description: This call should be made prior to starting a level, to obtain any data that the game has previously stored for the level about to be played. This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off. Examples of this can include fetching the data of a previous level (to indicate what items a user has in their in-game inventory). This is an asynchronous call, as the data may need to be fetched from a back-end server, thus the data is passed into a callback function that you must supply to the result function in the returned object. You should also make a call to iConsole.ads.show with the type set to levelStarted as well, and wait for both callbacks to complete before continuing on with the game. Suggested order would be to call iConsole.ads.show first, and then call iConsole.game.getLevelData to ensure that the user is presented with something that is the game just waiting, and only proceed once both of these functions have triggered their callback functions.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   level: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved)

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the user's level data is returned. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains a key data that is an object of the users data. Any other data other than the data that may be returned in this object block is deprecated and should not be relied upon.

classitems.name: getLevelData
example:
iConsole.game.getLevelData( { level: 23 } ).result( function ( resultData ) {
   myGame.decipherUsersLevelInformation( resultData.data );
} );

classitems.description:
This call should be made to store progress of a level (typically at the end of a level) via a 2k data string.
This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off or to restart previously failed
levels. Whilst this may result in a back-end call, this call can be made and no callback function required to
handle the result.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   level: 
   data: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved) and the data is a string of up to 2048 characters to store, where the contents of this are freely under the control of the game developer.

return.description: The return object is not required

classitems.name: setLevelData

classitems.description:
This call can be made prior to starting a level or prior to starting a game, to obtain any data that the game
has previously stored for the entire game session and any previous information (such as my best score if the
game wishes to display that inside its UI). This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where
they left off, for example by storing the current user level. This is an asynchronous call, as the data may
need to be fetched from a back-end server, thus the data is passed into a callback function that you must
supply to the result function in the returned object.

params.name: data
params.description: not used but provided in case of future API changes

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the user's game data is returned. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that contains a key data that is an object of the users data. Any other data other than the data that may be returned in this object block is deprecated and should not be relied upon.

classitems.name: getGameData

classitems.description:
This call should be made to store progress in a game session (typically at the end of a level) via a 2k data
string. This is useful to allow a user to continue game progress where they left off or to restart previously
failed levels. Whilst this may result in a back-end call, this call can be made and no callback function
required to handle the result.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   data: 
}
where the level number is any integer from -2147483647 to 2147483647 (-2147483648 is specially reserved) and the data is a string of up to 2048 characters to store, where the contents of this are freely under the control of the game developer.

return.description: The return object is not required

classitems.name: setGameData

classitems.description: This call should be made whenever the game wishes to post a high score for the global leaderboards for the user. In the future, the console may cause a dialog to appear to congratulate the user on their achievement and so the game should pause execution until the callback function that should be supplied to the result member function of the returned object has been called. Currently, this will be called immediately.

params.name: data
params.description:
{
   score: 
}
where the score is an integer of the users high score they achieved.

return.description:
An object that contains a member function result that you should call with a callback function that will be fired when the high score has been posted and any console interaction resulting from this has completed. The format of result function is 
result( callbackFunction );
Where callbackFunction is a function that will be called with a single parameter, an object that currently contains no data.

classitems.name: postHighScore

classitems.description:
The user may generate keydown events when they are typing either in the game or in the console. Where the
user is typing into their chat window, keydown events are going to be triggered that games will erroneously
catch and handle. Therefore, instead of registering keydown handlers inside the game, you should add a
handler to the iConsole instead, which will bubble the keydown events except for when the user is typing into
fields that shouldn't trigger game interaction, such as the chat window.
See iConsole.game.offEvent
classitems.name: onEvent

params.name: eventType
params.description: currently, the only supported event type is keydown

params.name: callbackFunction
params.description: a callback function that will be called every time the console determines a keydown event that should be passed to the game. It will be supplied with a cut down event object, that contains two member variables which and keyCode and a function stopPropagation that can be used to prevent bubbling of the event within the game (if your game registers multiple handlers to the console).

classitems.description:
The user may generate keydown events when they are typing either in the game or in the console. Where the
user is typing into their chat window, keydown events are going to be triggered that games will erroneously
catch and handle. Therefore, instead of registering keydown handlers inside the game, you should add a
handler to the iConsole instead, which will bubble the keydown events except for when the user is typing into
fields that shouldn't trigger game interaction, such as the chat window. This call will be used to
de-register the keydown handler.
See iConsole.game.onEvent
classitems.name: offEvent

params.name: eventType
params.description: currently, the only supported event type is keydown

params.name: callbackFunction
params.description: the callback function that was previously registered with iConsole.game.onEvent
